summary: acute bronchiolitis is a major cause for hospitalisation in young children during the winter season. human Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) is the most frequently identified virus. double viral infection is relatively common, occurring in about 10-30% of hospitalised patients. bronchiolitis was defined as acute respiratory disease, accompanied by coryza, cough, inspiratory crackles and/or expiratory wheezing on auscultation. infants with chronic lung disease, congenital heart disease and Down’s syndrome excluded. patients shared a two- or four-bed room, with beds separated at least 1.5 meter. cohorting of patients commenced as soon as the result of RSV-PCR was known.
